claim: The heart is located in the right side of the chest

supporting.text: Human anatomy textbooks consistently describe the heart as being located in the left side of the chest, specifically within the mediastinum.

attacks.text: Human anatomy textbooks consistently describe the heart as being located in the left side of the chest, specifically within the mediastinum.
In rare cases of situs inversus, a congenital condition, the heart is located on the right side of the chest.
Situs inversus affects only about 1 in 10,000 people, making it an extreme exception rather than a normative anatomical feature.
Some medical imaging studies show minor variations in heart position even in normal individuals, sometimes appearing more centered or slightly rightward.
These minor positional variations still fall within the clinically accepted 'left side' classification and don't constitute right-sided placement.

supporting.text: Medical imaging techniques such as X-rays and CT scans routinely show the heart positioned predominantly on the left side of the thoracic cavity.

attacks.text: Medical imaging techniques such as X-rays and CT scans routinely show the heart positioned predominantly on the left side of the thoracic cavity.
In rare cases of situs inversus, the heart is located on the right side of the chest.
Situs inversus is extremely rare, occurring in only about 1 in 10,000 people, making it statistically insignificant for general claims about heart location.
Some medical imaging techniques may produce mirrored images due to technical errors, showing the heart on the right side.
Modern medical imaging standards include strict protocols to prevent and detect mirrored images, making such errors highly unlikely in routine practice.

supporting.text: The apex of the heart, which is its lowest and most pointed part, is directed downward, forward, and to the left, further confirming its left-sided position.

attacks.text: The apex of the heart, which is its lowest and most pointed part, is directed downward, forward, and to the left, further confirming its left-sided position.
In rare cases of dextrocardia, the heart is mirrored and located on the right side of the chest.
Dextrocardia is an extremely rare condition, affecting less than 0.01% of the population, making it statistically insignificant for general claims about heart position.
The heart's position can shift slightly due to respiration or body position, sometimes appearing more centered or rightward.
While minor positional shifts occur, the heart's anatomical structure and apex orientation consistently favor the left side in normal physiology.

supporting.text: Situs solitus, the normal arrangement of thoracic and abdominal organs, places the heart on the left side of the body in the vast majority of humans.

attacks.text: Situs solitus, the normal arrangement of thoracic and abdominal organs, places the heart on the left side of the body in the vast majority of humans.
In rare cases of situs inversus, the heart is located on the right side of the chest.
Situs inversus occurs in only about 1 in 10,000 people, making it statistically insignificant for general anatomical descriptions.
Even in situs inversus, the heart's internal structure remains mirrored, maintaining functional equivalence to situs solitus.

supporting.text: Cardiac auscultation, a standard clinical examination technique, relies on left-sided placement of heart valves and sounds for accurate diagnosis.

attacks.text: Cardiac auscultation, a standard clinical examination technique, relies on left-sided placement of heart valves and sounds for accurate diagnosis.
